Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Photodissociation Dynamics Studied by Velocity-Mapped Ion Imaging
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this new award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanism Program A (CSDM-A) of the Division of Chemistry supports Professor Jeffrey A. Bartz of Kalamazoo College in a project investigating the dynamics of photochemical bond breaking in a series of gaseous molecules. The studies will evaluate the influence of the shape of the starting molecules on the mechanics of their dissociation. This research, which will be carried out by undergraduate students who will receive training in chemical dynamics, vacuum techniques and laser technology, will contribute to our understanding of processes involved in atmospheric chemistry.

The project will involve photodissociation studies of NO and OH containing molecules in which velocity mapped ion imaging will be used to measure the dynamics and orientation of the NO and OH fragments. An important goal of the project is the elucidation of the role of the conformations of the starting molecules on the dynamics of photodissociation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When a molecule absorbs light it can fragment. The characteristics of that photodissociation process and dynamic properties of the fragments themselves give a detailed picture of how the molecule is excited and what happens when it falls apart. We studied the photodissociation of a series of molecules in a velocity-mapped ion imaging (VMI) apparatus using nanosecond Nd:YAG and dye lasers. The VMI apparatus lets us differentiate between photodissociation events from different molecules in the beam because the products emerge with different speeds and/or alignments. The speeds are determined by the position an ion strikes the detector. The vector correlations between and among the transition dipole (µ), the velocity (v), and angular momentum (J) are determined by using polarized lasers to dissociate the parent and probe the product velocity and angular momentum distributions. 

In the grant period, we looked at four molecules, methyl nitrite [CH3ONO], t-butyl nitrite [(CH3)3CONO], nitrous acid [HONO], and dinitrogen trioxide [N2O3]. All the molecules fragmented to generate NO, a fragment yet also a stable molecule that is easy to detect using laser-based methods. In all cases we found a prompt dissociation with varying amounts of angular momentum alignment in the laboratory frame.

The education of Kalamazoo College students is enhanced in a research-rich environment. First, students learn to persevere through unpredicted challenges in their research projects. Second, students learn valuable research skills that they can use in their future careers. Third, students gain satisfaction by sharing their results at scientific meetings. Students supported by this NSF grant presented their work at the American Chemical Society National Meeting, the National Conference on Undergraduate Research, and the Pacific Conference on Spectroscopy and Dynamics. After the meetings, their posters hang in the Chemistry Department to acknowledge the work and encourage others to pursue undergraduate research. Nine Kalamazoo College students contributed significantly to this work.
